Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. In plants, photosynthetic guard cells on the surface of leaves form pores called stomata (a single pore is called a stoma). Stomata help prevent water loss and control gas exchange with the environment to maintain plant homeostasis. The turgor pressure of the guard cells on either side of the stomata determines whether the stomata are open or closed based on the transport of certain ions into and out of the guard cells (Figure 1). A proton pump in the membrane of the guard cells pumps protons into the extracellular space. This makes the interior of the cell more negatively charged than the extracellular space. Figure 1. Models of open and closed stomata and the transport proteins in the guard cell membranes Scientists interested in understanding drought tolerance in plants discovered a mutant variety of a plant with increased cell division, increased water content, and reduced density of leaf stomata compared with the wild type. Analysis of the mutant plant showed a mutation in the gene encoding a cyclin-dependent kinase (<math alttext="C D K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). This mutation prevents <math alttext="C D K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-cyclin interaction that normally results in the phosphorylation of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase (Figure 2). Figure 2. In wild-type plants, the wild-type <math alttext="C D K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein (<math alttext="C D K W T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK-WT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) allows interaction with a cyclin and leads to the phosphorylation of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase. In mutant plants, the mutant <math alttext="C D K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein (<math alttext="C D K M U T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CDK-Mut</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) prevents interaction with cyclin and the phosphorylation of <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase. (a) Describe the movement of <math alttext="K with a plus one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions into the guard cell based on the model in Figure 1. Scientists crossed plants that were homozygous for the cyclin dependent kinase-wild type (<math alttext="C D K W T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">CDK-WT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) allele with plants that were homozygous for the cyclin dependent kinase-mutant (<math alttext="C D K M U T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">CDK-Mut</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) allele. The <math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> offspring of this cross were then crossed, producing <math alttext="F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> offspring. Explain how the ratio of phenotypes in the <math alttext="F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> generation would demonstrate that the <math alttext="C D K M U T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">CDK-Mut</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> allele is recessive.
